Datatable.LocalizationPair: Rejuvenation Field

A relic of the Endless, doubtless constructed at the time of their civil wars, this Dust-energized anomaly heals and repairs ships that pass through its sphere of effect. Ancient ruins indicate it was once known as the "Lodestone of the Nine".

Ice Age

According to your scientists, this icy planet holds a secret: it was once a planet-sized factory owned by the Endless, the first spacefaring people to harness the power of Dust. The Endless are extinct now, but if they left any traces of their civilization behind, they'd be frozen miles under the surface.
Perhaps their archaeological remains may still hold valuable lessons for you and your empire. But how will you dig through all that ice?
Terraform the Frozen Planet
Terraform the planet $QuestPlanetName into a Temperate planet.
Unlock terraformation technologies from the Science and Exploration quadrant of the Tech Tree.
This Quest has failed

Despite all your efforts, not much of the Endless civilization remains here: it seems a long succession of sentient species inhabited this planet in the eons after the Endless's demise. Traces of the Endless have been all but wiped out. It wasn't a complete waste of time, however. You managed to unearth a set of ancient ship technology blueprints that seem to perform very efficiently, even by modern standards.
Foreign Contaminant

One of your exploratory drones, used by your team for rapid planetary assessment, has disappeared. According to your lead technician, this type of drone has a particularly low malfunction rate. He thinks it was intentionally sent off course by someone... or something. The drone has a cargo bay for collecting samples. Perhaps if you find it, you might discover what happened to it.
Two sites look like promising leads. They're both in difficult locations though, and recovery will be expensive--and possibly dangerous.
Explore the Quest Curiosities on the planet $QuestPlanetName. Each expedition will cost $Amount01Name [Strat01titaniumColored] #3C98FF#Titanium#REVERT#.
If you've used up all your probes, you will need to wait for a cooldown period for replenishment.

A strange sight greets the expedition team at the second site. The drone is partially sunk in swampland, close to another abandoned vessel. From the tangled growths ensnaring the vessel, it's clear it's been here a long time. You find no sign of any crew, but do manage to reactivate the craft. It'll make a useful addition to your fleets.
This Quest has failed
Pirate Ship spawned on System $QuestSystem01Name
Vital Statistics

The Galactic Census is coming up, and although you have greater worries on your mind, you remember what one of your wisest advisors once said: that a great leader is often judged not by his actions, but by the statistics he leaves behind. Perhaps it is worth investing a bit of effort to leave your mark on history--as the databases will remember it.
Parade
Building a military armada stronger than anything seen before will ensure your name is writ large in the history books.
In less than $Timer [turn] Turns, possess $Amount06Name Ships of at least $Amount03Name [offensiveMilitaryPower] offensive power.
Add Attack Modules to Ships to increase their Offensive Power.
The military parade wows the crowds, and the statisticians confirm that such a powerful fleet is unprecedented. You will be remembered as a great defender of your people.
Build
An era of unfettered construction will see the skylines of your biggest cities transformed, and your legacy secured.
In less than $Timer [turn] turns, generate $Amount04Name [industryColored] in one of your Systems.
Build Industry-generating constructions, and bring in Industry-focused Populations to the System.
Your system has become a beacon of industrial might, ready to construct whatever your empire needs. No leader has built a stronger base, and your name will be forever synonomous with strength.
Hoard
Economic might, more than any other program, will secure your legacy. Amass a Dust fortune that will never be forgotten.
In less than $Timer [turn] turns, stockpile $Amount05Name [dustColored] in your Empire.
Build Dust-generating constructions, create Trading Companies, and lower spending to bolster Dust reserves.
The Empire Treasury overflows with Dust, the wealth enough to make many dreams reality. Your stats are the envy of the galaxy.
This Quest has failed
The Lost Expedition

The expedition made landfall days ago, but nothing has been heard since they entered a region of mild seismic activity on the second day. Electromagnetic analysis of the region suggests that their communication equipment should still be functional, so lack of contact is unlikely to have a technical cause. What should you do? Stay loyal to the missing team and send another party down to investigate? Or keep everyone aboard, and not expose them to unknown risks? You have a bad feeling about this . . .
Rescue

You owe the expedition team your loyalty--after all, who will serve you in the future if they think you will abandon them at the first sign of danger? Your scientific counsel, however, has advised you that the action is not without risk. They estimate a 20% chance of the entire Fleet undertaking the search being lost.
Search the Curiosity on the planet $QuestPlanetName if you're ready to sacrifice $Amount01Name [Strat02hyperiumColored] #EAD085#hyperium#REVERT#… and maybe your Fleet.
A rescue party will cost [Strat02hyperiumColored] #EAD085#hyperium#REVERT# and may result in the loss of the entire Fleet.
The rescue party touches down on the planet, close to the site of the last known contact . . .
Protect

Only a fool would repeat the same action, and expect a different result. Without more information, mounting a rescue expedition would only jeopardise the lives of more of your people. It's an unpalatable truth, but sometimes exploring alien worlds is dangerous. The best you can do is honor the memories of those who were lost.
Rename the $MyColonizedSystemLocationName System to honor the lost.
If this System is lost before you change its name, you'll fail the quest. To rename a System, go in it management view and click on the existing name and write a new one.
Here stands $MyColonizedSystemLocationName, dedicated to the heroism of the fallen explorers.
This quest has failed
Unknown consequences...
Quick Learners

Though the Vaulters began their journey through the stars as an almost medieval society, their adaptability and intelligence have turned them into an efficient, advanced workforce. From the fearful refugees on the Argosy to the confident craftsmen and explorers of today, this people has come a long way. Sadly, they are torn between those who feel nostalgia for their past, and others who have an overt desire to forget it. Something needs to be done to either turn the former away from melancholy, or to help the latter remember their traditions. For if serious schisms form within the Vaulters, their innate drive to take care of the clans first will make everything else secondary--work, politeness, and public order included.
THE DUST
Look to the future; it appears plentiful and full of hope.
Produce $Amount01Name [dustColored] per turn in your Empire before $Timer [turn].
If your Vaulter population falls to 0, this quest will fail.

Though occasionally dour and begrudging, a concerted effort to improve living conditions and invest for the future brings positive results. Though they are no more garrulous, the Vaulters do at least crack an occasional smile.
THE DEPOSITS
Respect your past, and study the ancient crafts of your people.
Possess $Amount03Name Strategic Deposits in your Empire before $Timer [turn].
If your Vaulter population falls to 0, this quest will fail.

Starting with workshops in schools and extending to adult education and social clubs, a renaissance of ancient techniques for crafting metal, cloth, and leather create a greater appreciation for their ancestors. The Vaulter population is happier, and some now make a living crafting traditional objects.
A Cold Homecoming

You have found Auriga, the place from which your people departed ages ago. There seems to be no sign of life; the fate of those you left behind will require further investigation. Regardless, there is some cold satisfaction in knowing that the desperate escape from a dying planet was ultimately a success.
Melancholy
While your scientists learn much, your people mourn their lifeless home.
Traces of Ancestors

The act of colonization gives you the time and resources necessary to thoroughly explore the planet. Ancient galleries and halls are discovered, linked to great cave systems and mines far below the surface. Though it speaks to you of the genius and strength of your people, you find no evidence that they survived. Nor, however, do you find evidence that they died and were buried here...
Bereavement
It seems that the Vaulters who were left behind ages ago have disappeared; only the most optimistic believe they remain alive.
Any Good Lair Has a Back Door

The Pirate League has been crushed! Though a few scattered fleets may continue their line of work, the galaxy has become a safer and more predictable place to do business. More boring, yes, but more predictable. It seems, however, that the leader of the League was as wily as his reputation indicated, as he has escaped with a small but powerful fleet to continue his briefly interrupted career. We can't have that, can we?
HUNT
Find and defeat the Pirate League leader's fleet and take his loot for yourself
You must defeat the Hero ship that the pirate leader is using.

Grumpy and belligerent, Fluffpetal Gurk'Zvar stands before you. While he grudgingly accepts his fate, he would prefer to live out his life in blood and battle than in a prison cell. Why waste his particular talents? His only condition is that you never, ever ask him where his first name came from. Too bad. There must be an interesting story there...
Others were faster--or perhaps just greedier--than you. The ship and the pirate will be working for someone else.

Underground Citadel

Constructed using original Aurigan designs found in the deepest recesses of the Argosy's archives, the Underground Citadel permits valuable infrastructure and populations to be housed beneath the surface, where they enjoy enhanced protection from ground invasions. In addition, vast subterranean barracks within the citadel boost manpower numbers.
-50% [population] population loss probability in case of invasion -50% [improvement] building loss probability in case of invasion
Geological Vault

Given the generations that the Vaulter's ancestors spent toiling beneath the frozen and tainted Aurigan surface, it is no surprise that they became masters at finding every conceivable use for the rare minerals and weird bioforms they discovered in the darkness. With this facility, scientific progress can flourish, especially if the system contains luxury deposits.
Conscription Complex

This massive industrial complex can be built in order to take better advantage of the available labor raised through military or civil service requirements. Skilled hands and trained soldiers work together, improving system defenses and generating useful industrial output.
System Science Station

This publicly accessible space platform, somewhere between museum, laboratory, and theme park, turns the science of anomaly study into a place where children and adults can both learn and play. With the null-g roller coaster next to the large array telescope, there's something for everyone.
Filter Barges
Guided by sensor systems, these automated fleets scour a given system, filtering traces of valuable resources from dust, asteroids, and any other natural or artificial debris.
Research Cities

By government decree, vast regions are dedicated to scientific research and engineering development. By including massive projects such as particle accelerators and cutting-edge science museums, huge swathes of the population are happy to both work and play in these centers.
Aurigan History Center

A center dedicated both to the cultural history of the Aurigan people and the lore and legend of the planet they departed, this center is of great interest to many different citizens of the galaxy. By promoting their culture and sharing their experiences, great benefits are accrued to the Vaulter peoples.
Budakai Bunkers

These installations are named for an ancient site on Auriga that was an ancient capital of the people. As the legendary city was part underground, so these bunkers are rugged, vast, and highly defensible.
Portal
The Vaulters extensive use of portals on Auriga, plus their advanced knowledge of Dust and Strategic Resources, allows them to teleport fleets between systems.
Allows the teleportation of fleets between two systems containing this improvement. Note: Trade Routes and Trading Companies do not use Portal routes, they are mililtary-only.
Vaulters

An ancient faction, the Vaulters suffered continual setbacks in trying to establish a permanent home for themselves. Not so much restless wanderers as adaptable pragmatists, their centuries of travel and tinkering have made them skilled at both science and warfare. Defense remains their preferred military strategy, and their grim tenacity makes them effective defenders. They have a tradition of appointing female leaders, and their history of escaping and surviving to fight another day continually reaffirms it. The Vaulters left the planet of Auriga when potentially cataclysmic geo-atmospheric problems were detected. Having left their homes, gods, and many of their people behind them, the dream of regaining these things has gained an almost mythical status.
Sisters of Mercy

Having known only the harsh world of Auriga, the Sisters of Mercy are adapting to the strangeness of life in space with some difficulty. Fortunately, their study and travel with the Vaulters has alleviated some of their shock and sense of displacement. As they attempt to rebuild a functioning society in this alien galaxy, they cling more than ever to their mission: Dispensing death or salvation as the situation merits. The practicing clans of the Sisters of Mercy try hard to separate the relative aspects of any situation--technology, cultural norms, history--from the absolutes of their faith--the belief in a universally applicable sense of right and wrong, and the responsibility to treat harshly those who cross the line between them.

Metafolding

Vaulter technology, created from relics, genius, and inspiration, permits the exploitation of "thin places" where folds between two spatially distant points within the multiverse allow instantaneous movements from one system to another.
The Sundered of Auriga

This is a stubborn, resilient people that have spent centuries seeking a home. Stranded on the world of Auriga, they had to survive the harsh climate and even harsher neighbors. In a years-long effort, they managed to repair their ancient colony ship, the Argosy, and once again depart before the dying planet became their grave. Once more among the stars, the people that now call themselves the Aurigans still seek traces of their past as well as a safe place to build their future.
Sisters of Mercy
Inflexible but honest, the Sisters of Mercy are fierce in battle and inspiring in peace.
Healers
Tapping into vast knowledge bases, this faction can heal wounded individuals faster and also apply this knowledge to repair machines.
First Line Defensive Preparations
Blessings & Bandages
By stockpiling medical products and preparing psychological support systems for ground troops, defenders have a great health advantage during planetary invasions.
Heightened Patriotism through Self-Reliance Charter
Victory Gardening

Across the empire, whether they live in vast breadbaskets or arid wastelands, citizens are mandated with producing their own food supplies. Communal hydroponic farms, vertical allotments, fungal gardens--anything that produces digestible edibles is allowed. Aside from boosting food production, the real benefit is a greater sense of loyalty to the motherland.

Advanced Topology Algorithms
An understanding of the mathematics of high-dimensional surfaces is practical for advancing the sciences of ship movement, wormholes, and dimensional travel.
Adaptive ERA Materials

Vaulter scientists and engineers have successfully adapted the theories of electromagnetic reactive armor into ship shielding and hulls. Inspiration came from successful enemies as well as their own innovations.
Space Loop

Advances in public transport and materials permit the creation of flexible tubes that can deliver passengers from a planet's surface to low orbit in a matter of hours. Exploitation of public space infrastructures becomes an easy goal.
Aurigan Shielding
Arcane technologies discovered beneath Auriga, coupled with extensive data collected during the voyage on the Argosy, has led Vaulter scientists to develop improved shielding technology.
Hardship Bonus Incentives

By defining certain actions as particularly valuable for the empire and remunerating those who undertake them, Vaulter leadership encourages actions that might not normally occur. A delicate and potentially expensive system, it nevertheless accelerates the completion of difficult projects.
Hyperfolding
Advanced knowledge of the folding techniques shows methods and engine designs that could improve the performance of ships using the Metafold drive.
History Mine

This technology creates enormous data mines of historical records, even from non-binary and non-electronic data sources. Though the goal is to create a searchable database of both Vaulter and galactic history, there are numerous applications in communications, political science, marketing, and education.
Ex-Atmospheric Filtration

Technology and processes used to reduce toxic elements in the atmosphere can be adapted for use in a vacuum. Vaulter engineers have improved this terraforming technology so it can also be used in space.
Dimensional Metafolding
By combining their portal technology with the science of zero-point fields, Vaulter engineers have developed methods that dimensionally compress objects both locally and across vast distances.
Universal Conscription

Every citizen has a use and a skill. Regardless of intelligence level or potential handicap, all Vaulters are expected to dedicate between 6 months and two years of their life to public service either in the military, social services, or research and development.
Advanced Strike Force

Combining technologies for personnel transport and survivability has lead to several advances in attack technologies. Troops can be brought more rapidly to combat, wherever that is planetside or in space.
Megarisk Engineering

Extreme high-risk engineering projects are not usually undertaken on account of the chance of catastrophic failure which can lead to deaths, collateral damage, and adverse publicity. Specialized systems can be developed, based on defensive military technology, that channel or mitigate the destructive consequences. Using this, increasingly risky--and interesting--projects can be pursued.
Interstitial Spaces

Bringing together the best industrial engineers and scientific researchers and tasking them with designing multi-purpose spaces, where manufacturing plants can swiftly be co-opted into research hubs, led to significant gains in industrial productivity. With jobs and demand surging, many adventure seekers come looking for opportunities.

Basic Fold Drive

This is a basic form of Vaulter drive technology, freeing them from the necessity to use starlanes and cosmic string technology. Instead, Vaulter ships move directly between stars through a series of limited metaverse folds.
Hyperfold Hulls

Using advances in the metaverse folding technologies, both ships and colonies are outfitted with specialized warp fields that accelerate traversing metaverse folds. Ships can now move through folds using single movement points.
Argosy II

Due to the fact that advanced colonization systems require far less space and energy, much of the Argosy's capacity can be refit for other projects that require heavy equipment and high power--including the possibility of becoming a mobile Portal.
Portal use costs only 1 movement point (Note: Allied factions that have the Vaulters [Metafolding] affinity can share this bonus; other allies use the Portal without this effect).
Portal Upgrade: Manpower
Available bandwidth on the Portal is used to bring in Manpower to provide labor and troops.
Portal Upgrade: Wellness

An accidental discovery was made while researching advanced Portal technologies. Certain materials and energy sources, when used in specific combinations, create Portal emanations that have a naturally soothing effect on the system population.
Portal Upgrade: Broadcast

All traffic that passes via the Portal receives a brief mention on social communications channels--always with a positive, empire-friendly spin on it. Neighboring systems are flooded with continuous impressions of the strength and efficiency of your empire.
Portal Upgrade: Drydock
The enormous energy required to send and receive fleets via Portals is not always needed. Extensions can be built onto the Portal station that use this excess energy for ship refit and repair.
Open Source Defense Systems

Sciences that pertain to defensive systems are opened to public scrutiny and improvement. Professors, engineers, and hobbyists collaborate with governement contractors to accelerate and improve the knowledge generated by large-scale military projects.
Petrov Jutka

Another ghost from a long line of ghosts, Jutka always had an uncanny knack for infiltration and ambush operations. A natural warrior and unpredictable commander, her troops have a history of success and survival that make her the envy of friend and foe. While some say it must be in her genes, given her famous great-grandmother, Judit, her grueling training and relentless drive should also be taken into account when explaining her phenomenal success.
Serz Kersho

A troubled child with a history of violence, it took a brush with death and a prolonged convalescence with the Sisters of Mercy to change Kersho's world view. Developing meditation, concentration, and spirituality to contain his naturally bellicose nature, Kersho became a driven and ambitious explorer and champion of lost causes. Appreciated for his intensity and brilliance if feared for his edgy temper, he is a disruptive force to be reckoned with.
Raudd Klapatch

With a background in planetary ecology, Raudd nevertheless spent a great deal of time with a weapon in his hands as his specialization on Auriga was the biomes of Necrophage habitats. To this day he still travels fearlessly, if not recklessly, in his unchecked search for knowledge, though some say his time at the Academy improved his common sense and tempered his tendency to act before thinking.
Rill Kata

A promising young student of mechanisms and mathematics on Auriga, Kata converted to the Community of the Great Orrery after a near-death experience at fifteen when necrotic tissue in her foot almost took her life. The salvaged auto-medic apparatus that amputated the decaying limb and grafted on an artificial foot both saved her life and altered her outlook on the world. From that day, Kata rose to prominence as a fierce champion of the machine, and was a natural choice when it came to developing leaders and experts to survive in the dauntingly technological galaxy beyond their homeworld.
Vaulters
Vaulter heroes, like their people, appreciate and develop talents for exploration, discovery, and defense.
Vaulters Skills
This branch contains the Vaulters-specific skills.
Justicar Jyde Parcha

Parcha had both the doom and the honor to leave Auriga and cross the stars when the Vaulters repaired the Argosy and departed. She travels with her family heirloom, the Book of the Kjrtys, an ancient tome filled with proverbs, anecdotes, and prayers. Whatever shadows or demons lurk behind the emotions that provoke a given situation, the Book is intended to provide her with the clarity of absolutes to deal with the problem. She discovered, however, that multiple layers of sentience, culture, and civilization impose far more complexity than her simple philosophical training provided. In search of greater answers, she visited the Academy and became one of the very few non-Dust-enhanced individuals admitted to its inner sanctum and taught its secrets. Fascinated by her experiences on Auriga, Isyander himself ensured that Parcha mastered Dust and became a full member of the Academy.
Sisters of Mercy
The Sisters are known for dispensing justice as they see fit, whether that is a healing hand or a striking blade.
Fluffpetal Gurk'Zvar

A rough character from a rough culture, Gurk’Zvar would have been a hard case even if his drunken stepfather had not named him Fluffpetal. A name like that in Gnashast society made bullying a daily occurrence throughout his youth. Before he learned anything else, Gurk'Zvar learned how to win fights or talk his way out of them. Showing a lot more smarts than his parents, Gurk'Zvar figured out that more friends and more people who owe you favors translated into more clout on the streets. From gang leader to mob boss was relatively straightforward, and once he took his first trip off-planet it was clear that nothing short of ruling his own pirate empire would be enough for this bright and belligerent personality.

Chapter 1. A New World – Part 1

We left Auriga millennia ago--but to us it feels like yesterday. Slumbering in our pods aboard the Argosy, time was only marked by cold, fleeting dreams drawn out over centuries. Upon awakening I could still remember a million details of the day of our departure: the biting winter wind; the smell of the ash-fires along the route to the vessel; the bone-shaking rumble of the engines as we speared into the icy depths of space and Auriga receded to nothing. Most of all, the guilt, black and heavy in the pit of my stomach, for the kin we left behind. I might have been overwhelmed by these memories, had it not been for the crisis that greeted my waking. Our carefully restored craft, the life-saving Argosy, had suffered a grievous wound. Some cataclysmic explosion had knocked us off course, playing havoc with our systems. Opbot--brave, loyal Opbot--did everything it could to avert catastrophe and get us back on course. But even its heroic efforts weren't enough, for eventually the power failed and we were left to drift. It is nothing less than a miracle that we awoke, circling that Endless ruin adrift in space. Our priority was settling a world and surviving. Even if this planet is not a home, it will at least be a refuge. And so here we are, possibly safe, and yet immediately plunged into another crisis. For no sooner had we planted the Vaulter flag into this alien soil than we lost our talisman, the ancient machine who saved so many of us by guiding us through the long night. Opbot has disappeared. We scoured the local caverns and crevices, the cliffs and bogs, the treetops scanning the wilderness. But the truth is even stranger. As we skim, I hear news from the base, even the rushing wind and the radio crackle unable to disguise the words. "One of the interstellar shuttles is missing," the voice says. "Opbot must've left the system."
SENTINELS
The disappearance of Opbot is a worry, but things must be dealt with in turn. We must first assure our own survival before we can seek Opbot and our lost kin.
Build $Amount01Name #B82738#Defensive#REVERT# or #B82738#Ship Improvement#REVERT# Star System Improvements or Wonders in the Empire
Note: The same building (except Wonders) can be built on several Systems.

For the first time in ages we feel secure. We feel, perhaps, hope… But it is in our blood to turn outwards and seek when others would turn inwards and hide. Opbot is missing, we left much of our kin on Auriga, and somewhere out in the galaxy lies the planet Mezan--where our journey began ages ago.
SEEKERS

My kin, so used to scientific supremacy, are more backward than the other species in this galaxy. We must grow in leaps and bounds in our scientific knowledge, or we will fade and wither to become inbred cripples in the galactic backwaters.
Build $Amount01Name #52c9e7#scientific#REVERT# Star System Improvements or Wonders.
Note: The same building (except Wonders) can be built on several Systems.

I dare to feel a sense of confidence and hope that I have not felt for ages. We have done much and learned much in a brief time; I feel a surge of joy and affection when I see the resolve with which we Aurigans face our future.
Chapter 1. A New World – Part 2

Opbot's location and its reasons for disappearing remain a mystery. As much as I would like to dwell on that, I have other requests that I must respond to. The greatest is the demand of my kin to answer the myriad unanswered questions about our own past: Where was the world of Mezan, from which legend says we once came? What remains of its people? And where is Auriga, once our home, now lost in the galactic cloud since the Dust explosion shifted the Argosy and confused our navigation systems? My kin have done well, so I will do this for them rather than urging them forward. In truth, I am concerned that until their queries about our past are answered, they will not be ready to look ahead. My thoughts have now turned to the Argosy, which has been re-supplied and refurbished in the rush of colonization. In the age when it was built the vessel was an interstellar ship, and we may now have the ability to recover information from its records that we could not have obtained years ago. At the same time, we will interrogate other species and other sources of information. Anomalies, the highly Dust-active lodes of special resources, anything that can tell us of the evolution and history of this galaxy is of value. For the galaxy moves and expands; worlds and systems are moving targets and our science still lacks the accuracy to track them.
INTERROGATE
Our science and our experience is great, but is that of only one species. We must also interrogate other species, even if they divulge their secrets unwillingly.
Win $Amount01Name Fleet Battles
Design and build Ships and put them into Fleets. To battle!

From everything we have learned from other peoples, the answers are saddening. By all reliable accounts, Mezan is a dead planet; overexploited and turned into a barren ruin by the combines of the empire. The Mezari are lost to us, so I will turn to our more recent past--the kin that stayed on Auriga. We must find the planet, and reunite with survivors—if any still remain, millennia later.
ANALYZE

The unusual properties of anomalies can be studied; many of them hold stores of data on galactic conditions whether or not they are aware of it. In Dust and in dust, we will seek ancient maps of the galaxy and compare them to the old records from the Argosy.
Possess $Amount02Name anomalies on colonized planets on your Empire
Colonize a planet with an anomaly to add it to your Empire

Deep scans of space and of the planets themselves have yielded information--waves captured by fields, asteroids filled with galactic dust, and even ruins of ancient stargazing peoples. By all accounts the Mezari are lost to us; the planet that we once called home was turned into a barren wasteland by overexploitation. I will turn to our more recent past--the kin that stayed on Auriga. We must find the planet, and reunite with survivors—if any still remain, millennia later.

In the age when it was built the vessel was an interstellar ship, and we may now have the ability to recover information from its records that we could not have obtained years ago. At the same time, we will interrogate other species and other sources of information. The lairs of other drifters in the galactic starlanes are also centers of information, however they may have obtained it. They may be pirates, but to desperate Aurigans they could also be useful associates. The galaxy moves and expands; worlds and systems are moving targets and our science still lacks the accuracy to track them. Perhaps the brigands of the galaxy could provide some of that.
SUPPRESS
It is best to get information when you negotiate from a position of power. Pirates will divulge information more readily if your boots are on their throats.
Destroy the Pirate Lair on the System $ClosePirateLairName.
You will need to mount an Invasion to destroy the Lair, and that will require Manpower.

With nothing left to lose, the pirates showed no interest in hiding any secrets. The truth, however, is dismal. By all accounts, Mezan is a dead planet; overexploited and turned into a barren ruin by the combines of the empire. The Mezari are lost to us, so I must turn to our more recent past--the kin that stayed on Auriga. We must find the planet, and reunite with survivors—if any still remain, millennia later.
SYMPATHIZE

The pirate lairs are filled with people not so different from the way you were--without a home planet, cut off from their roots, and desperate to survive. From your position of strength you can show pity; speak with them, rather than destroy them.
Reach a standing of "Cordial" with the Pirates and maintain it for $DurationName [turn].
You can use "Pirate Diplomacy" to manage your relations with the Lair.

With scavenged objects and collected rumors from across the galaxy, we have found our answers. And we do not like them. By all accounts the Mezari are lost to us; the planet that we once called home was turned into a barren wasteland by overexploitation. So now I turn to our more recent past--the kin that stayed on Auriga. We must find the planet, and reunite with survivors—if any still remain, millennia later.
Chapter 2. The Search for Auriga

We used to believe in "The Great Orrery"; that there existed a system of mechanics that underlay all of the reality that we perceive. Our priests were Sentinels and Seekers; either guardians of our people and our traditions or explorers and scientists whose holy purpose was to further decrypt the orrery's mechanics. Though those beliefs now feel simple one element has remained: A fundamental belief in the fact that one day the orrery will align itself so that we can be reunited with our lost kin. The state of Mezan has broken some people's faith; they see a cold and hungry universe that swats us around like a cat playing with a wounded bird. But I won't give in to these frustrations, for what kind of leader would I be if I gave up? The day may come when all of our avenues are exhausted, when the promised home that we have sought for as long back as we can remember turns out to be a lie. On that day, I, too, may give up the hope of the alignment of the stars and the discovery of our lost home. But I will never give up on my people. Not while I live; not while I lead. And the next place to seek them is on Auriga, wherever that may be...
HUNT

Find the planet that you left ages ago, and search it with all the technology of an advanced fleet. You are hunting for the remains of your own people, who fled the surface when the endless winter came.
Search the Curiosity on $AurigaPlanetName planet with a fleet including a [ship] ship level $Amount01Name.
Hero ships are not included for the Ship Level. Rookies are from level 1 to level 3, Veteran from level 4 to level 6, and Elite from level 7 to level 9. Legendary is the final level.

It is one of those days when I must decide if I am angry, or sad. We found traces of our kin, and signs that they survived. But we did not find them; not their graves, not their bodies. Auriga has become a frozen planet, and she guards her secrets in an icy heart.
OBSERVE

Find the planet that you left ages ago, and search it. You are hunting for the remains of your own people, who fled the surface when the endless winter came. You will need additional hyperium to power the intensive scanning that will be necessary.
Search the Curiosity on $AurigaPlanetName planet when you're ready to sacrifice $Amount03Name [Strat02hyperiumColored] #EAD085#hyperium#REVERT#.
The [Strat02hyperiumColored] will be consumed.

It is one of those days when I must decide if I am angry, or sad. We found echoes of rebuilt galleries and chambers deep underground. It seems that they survived after we left, but we did not find them. Not even their graves or their bodies. Auriga has become a frozen planet, and she guards her secrets in an icy heart.

HUNTER

There is little confusion about the final readings: Auriga is simply not here. Did the Dust explosion send the Argosy to a parallel universe? Did it reduce Auriga to dust and rubble? We may find these answers one day, but right now the only fact of which I am sure is that the planet we came from is no longer in this galaxy.
OBSERVER

The galaxy is vast; discouragingly so. But you would not be the leader of a people if you only signed up for the easy jobs. Explore the galaxy until you find Auriga, or are sure that it is no longer there…
Discover $Amount02Name % of the Galaxy.
You will need Probes and perhaps Wormhole travel to achieve this.

There is little confusion about the final readings: Auriga is simply not here. Did the Dust explosion send the Argosy to a parallel universe? Did it reduce Auriga to dust and rubble? We may find these answers one day, but right now the only fact of which I am sure is that the planet we came from is no longer in this galaxy.
Chapter 3. The Heretic -- Part 1

Against my will, three days of mourning were declared. I feel the loss, perhaps more deeply than any, but we will never find ourselves if we wallow in the past and remember our losses. Every day that slips by is one of lost opportunities and missed chances; do my kin not see that we have to strive constantly if we are to be the ones in control of our destiny? There are still Aurigans that are alive, and my role is to see them flourish. Not merely survive. It was at this moment that a strange message came. Isyander, leader and founder of the Academy, has somehow heard of us, but more importantly, of our interest in Auriga. What interest could he have, this suit-entombed being with an unknown past and inscrutable loyalties? I do not feel strong enough to ignore or insult Isyander, so I accepted an audience with two of his Heroes--two of his Dust-enhanced superbeings. It is interesting to be in the presence of equals. But what they had to say was even stranger. Isyander claims not only knowledge of our history on Auriga, but knowledge of the kin we left behind. For the diplomats claim that there is a good reason that we found signs of life but not the bodies, nor the graves. They claim that some of our kin and "other beings of interest" are still alive, elsewhere in the galaxy. I must have this information, whatever the cost.
DISTRUST

The envoys have been polite, but there is no such thing as free information. There will be a demand--or a request couched as a demand, and perhaps the need to stage a rescue operation. When it comes, the Vaulters must be ready. Our fleets must be ready.
Possess at least $Amount01Name [ship] ships of $Amount02Name [defensiveMilitaryPower] Defensive military power.
Defensive power of ships can be increased through Shield, Plating, and some specialized Support modules.

Our fleets are ready, to seek and to protect. And now the secret is revealed: Isyander requests unlimited access to the memory banks of the hulk of the Argosy in return for his information. The science and Dust mastery of his Academy are far beyond ours, but his methods and goals are too incomprehensible for me to trust him. I sleep badly...
TRUST

Isyander and his envoys have shown only good faith. While I may be over-optimistic, I am willing to plan for the best outcome. Not merely as a commitment that we must follow through on, but as a beacon of hope for my kin.
Possess $Amount04Name [temperatureTemperate] temperate planets.
The planets can be possessed either by colonization or through terraformation.

With guarded optimism, we have found the planets we need. But now the other boot drops: Isyander requests unlimited access to the memory banks of the hulk of the Argosy in return for his information. The science and Dust mastery of his Academy are far beyond ours, but his methods and goals are too incomprehensible for me to trust him. What is best for my kin?
Chapter 3. The Heretic -- Part 2

The Heroes of the Academy and their leader, Isyander, have many awe-inspiring attributes. Brilliance, cleverness, rapidity of thought and of action, vast knowledge and understandings of both the past and the future. One of their great weaknesses, however, is pride. Or perhaps hubris. They speak in front of me in a rapid, coded language as if I would not understand it; they gesture between themselves in ways that they think are imperceptible. Yet I have been reading the body language of alien species for centuries, and I am enhanced in ways that would surprise them. Their thoughts and intentions are an open book to me. Did it never occur to them that First of the Bloodline is more than a simple matriarch of a primitive people? I have seen through their hints and mentions of other "beings". I know what they have as a bargaining chip to exchange for information about our lost kin. They have Opbot. I will not know the details until I speak with it myself, but it seems that Opbot made his way to the Academy. Or perhaps agents of Isyander made their way to Opbot; the details are not yet clear. But they will be. This I swear. So this will be what they will request of us: The extraction of the memory banks from the Argosy, so that Isyander and his geniuses might learn more of Auriga. In return, Opbot will be released to us with information about our lost kin. The deal seems simple and obvious, but it leaves too many questions unanswered. How and why did Opbot end up there? Why does Isyander show such an obsession with us--or with Auriga? And the biggest question, of course: What shall I do?
IGNORE

Opbot took its future into its own hands when it left the Argosy--for whatever reason. I do not trust Isyander's motives, and I will not sell out the history of my people on the Argosy--a history that one day we, too, will be able to read. Rather than make the exchange, I will prepare for war, for I doubt that Isyander will walk away from his obsession with the Argosy and Auriga.
Reach $Amount02Name Empire [manpower] manpower capacity in your Empire
This can be done using System Improvements and Luxury Resources, and by increasing Food production.

It seems that I read the ambassadors correctly. Opbot is indeed a hostage, or a visitor, or a prisoner… But it must make its own future in the galaxy, for I must choose my kin and my bloodline over it. And I am prepared for the war that may explode as a result of this. But I cannot help that; it is my duty, and it's who I am.
EXTRACT

It is not easy to decide, but my kin ask for the return of Opbot. Without it, our trip from Auriga would likely have gone on forever through the void. I do not like this, and I cannot trust Isyander until I understand his motives. But I can't ignore our lost kin, and our lost android friend. So we will copy what we can of the archives, and analyze them ourselves as well...
Reach $Amount05Name [scienceColored] per [turn] in your Empire.
This can be done using System Improvements, Planetary Improvements, and Luxury Resources.

My kin have achieved a level of science that surpasses even our ancestors who built the Argosy, and their new revelations have stunned us: It appears that Auriga was, as we believed, not merely a planet but an actor in the Great Orrery. A living thing. One of the beings that Isyander refers to as the "Lost". And Opbot, now home again, has confirmed Isyander's unhealthy obsession with these dead gods. But I am a simple person. First I will see to my kin, then Isyander's gods.
Final Chapter. Origins

My concerns about the motives of the Academy seem to have been correct. Though we have evolved, and the roles of our Sentinels and Seekers have changed, and our understanding of the wonders of the Great Orrery have shifted, Isyander's obsession seems as constant as a guiding star. Rumors tell of his blazing desire to uncover the secrets of his "Lost", and to repatriate to the Academy any relics or ruins that pertain to them. We have been--carefully-- tracking Academy fleets, and they have accelerated their explorations of the strange and ancient planets of the galaxy. Planets with Endless ruins appear to be of interest, but those with ruins even older than the Endless seem to be their most sought-after prizes. Curiously; one planet that seems to be of great interest is the barren planet of Mezan. None of us can guess what Mezan has to offer, but if it is interesting to Isyander, it is interesting to me. I have heard other rumors about our own origin, and I will not pass up the opportunity to tag along and see what the geniuses of the Academy might discover about the Vaulters! Shadowing Academy fleets can only work for so long before we are discovered. I must bring this situation to a conclusion as quickly as I can...
FIGHTERS
The Academy fleet is leaving, but you must have its data and conclusions. Stop it from getting away, bring it to its knees, and take its secrets for your people.
Defeat the Academy Fleet.
Plan your Battle Tactics and Ship Designs carefully!

A Hero sits before you, uncomfortably, in a chair designed to restrain and control her. She is a researcher, not a warrior, but her knowledge cuts like knives as she speaks. "Your people are the descendents of convicts; criminal scum who were shipped out to die on a vessel called the Success. You are an example of the filth that can only be cleansed by the return of the Lost." I shrug and release her. It is not happy news, but it is at least a reliable answer. Whatever we may have been then, we are something else now. We have been criminals, refugees, colonists, seekers... We are many things, and if the Great Orrery permits we shall become even greater things. Finally we must sit where we are, accept our fate, and find new questions. The Sentinels will guard, the Seekers will explore. We will always be the Vaulters.

The results coming from the new R&D center are as unfortunate as they are unshakeable. We can give up the search for our origins and ancestors, as it seems that they were hardened criminals sent out to live or die on a colonization ship, the Success. I manage a rueful smile. With a past like that, I am more than ever committed to looking toward the future! For whatever we may have been then, we are something else now. We have been criminals, refugees, colonists, seekers... We are many things, and if the Great Orrery permits we shall become even greater things. Finally we must sit where we are, accept our fate, and find new questions. The Sentinels will guard, the Seekers will explore we will always be the Vaulters.
SCHOLARS

Time and money spent on chasing Academy fleets is better spent on building up your own research ability. Build a new research center, capable of discovering the secrets that the Academy tries to keep.
This Empire Improvement can be buit in any System Consruction Queue

Isyander's Legions
Final Chapter. Reunification

Who would have thought you could have a homecoming party for a robot? But the return of Opbot has been, for some, like a national holiday or the reunification with a long-lost sibling. Opbot takes everything in its stride, somewhat distantly and politely, perhaps amused rather than appreciative. I do not know if it feels things like affection or happiness, but I am sure of one thing: It prefers being among people that trust and respect it. Unlike the tinkerers at the Academy, we have no desire to dissect Opbot in order to understand what makes it so unusual. But Opbot has returned with something equally precious: information on the destination and fate of our kin who left Auriga long after we did. During the centuries we slept they changed and evolved, for it was only by reactivating Endless technology, discovered deep within the heart of Auriga, that they were able to depart. I had to sit down when I heard this news; it is one thing to hope, and quite another to see those hopes materialize. We have information and a destination. We know that there are Aurigans, other Vaulters, out there in the galaxy, long cut off from the kin who took the Argosy. However they may have changed and whatever they are now does not matter. They are still my kin, they are still my responsibility, and I will not stop until all of my kin is reunited. My voice shakes as I give the orders.
DOMINATE

I don't know if Isyander or some other force has set traps for us. I must reunite the lost Aurigans with my kin, and the only sure way of doing this is to have a fleet that will make interception or interdiction impossible. I will reunite our people, and I will use all of our might to ensure that this happens.
Dock a fleet on the system Auriga 2.0 that has at least $Amount01Name [offensiveMilitaryPower] Offensive military power.
Increase the offensive power of a fleet by upgrading Ship Hulls and researching more powerful Modules.

The Great Orrery has ticked on, revealing its mechanisms grudgingly. We finally have some of the answers to our many questions. Our kin have been discovered and brought together, and we have some sense of closure on the fate of Mezan and Auriga. Some seem to feel that we have run out of questions, but that makes me laugh. We are reunited and we have a home that is truly ours, now at last we can turn outward and explore our future!
NEGOTIATE

It is a delicate thing, and I wonder if our lost kin even know of us. I will send Opbot as ambassador; I dare not go myself and it is the only other Vaulter that they may remember. I wonder if the Second of the Bloodline still lives with them, for her lifespan would be like mine. My daughter, Judit, my only child.
Send Opbot level $Amount03Name to orbit around the system Auriga 2.0
You can increase Hero levels by building Improvements (Governor) or winning battles (Admiral)

The Great Orrery has ticked on, revealing its mechanisms grudgingly. Finally, after these centuries of running and seeking, we can finally stop and think. We have learned the fate of our kin, come to grips with our past, and flushed the demons our of our dreams. And I? I have found a place in the galaxy for my people, and been reunited with a daughter who I was sure had become part of the Orrery. The Vaulters are reunited and reinvigorated. There is a galaxy out there to be explored and controlled, and beyond that, uncountable other galaxies. Forward, Vaulters, beyond the stars!
Auriga 2.0

Endless Space 2: Vaulters

This first expansion brings back one of the most popular factions of the Endless Universe: the Vaulters. Following the events that occurred in Endless Legend, this stubborn and resilient people have left the dying planet of Auriga, seeking a new home to build their future.

Leaving their home planet of Auriga behind in a desperate gamble for survival, the Vaulters find themselves drifting through space after a cataclysmic Dust explosion. They must settle a new system and strike out to find security for their people--then discover the fate of those they left behind. Led as always by the indomitable Zolya Ilona, First of the Bloodline, the Vaulters are still masters of military defense and scientific discovery. And, with luck, they will finally be masters of their own destiny...

Vaulters major civilization: - Vaulter faction gameplay - Vaulters ships - Five new Heroes - Vaulters faction Quest - Special node - Sisters of Mercy Minor Faction + Hero - Pirate diplomacy - Pirate quest + Hero - Exotic ship modules - Additional Deeds - Four new exploration quests
Vaulters

The Vaulters start off at a Special Node, the Rejuvenation Field They have a "Super Colonizer" ship (the Argosy) which is able to create a Colony directly (without first developing an Outpost). Your first task is to find a System for your initial Colony--the faster, the better!

Notice that the Senate and Technology screens are locked in addition to the Quest and Diplomatic Screens. Unlike all other factions, you don't start with a Colony. Until you have one, you cannot produce Science and Dust, build Improvements, etc. Your population is much more focused on survival than on politics! Find a good star system: explore with the Argosy via the starlanes.
Vaulters

The Argosy can #FFFF00#colonize#REVERT# this System. Each colonization will trigger a Golden Age, during which more resources are produced and Heroes gain experience more quickly. Note: Vaulters will suffer higher penalties if they colonize too many systems.
After colonizing this planet the Argosy will need $Amount01Name [turn] to refuel and reload. Even if it has been damaged and repaired, you may have still have to pay a cost to colonize if the ship is not ready: $Amount02Name additional [turn] cooldown but this duration also depends on the existing colonies amount.
Vaulters

Congratulations, you have created your first Colony! Note this building: #FFFF00#$PortalBuildingName#REVERT#. This is a Portal that lets your fleets teleport between your systems. If you build another $PortalBuildingName in another colony, your fleets will be able to teleport instantly from one to the other. Vaulters don't need to have their systems close to each other for defense; they are always nearby if you have built Portals.
THE STARS MY DESTINATION

Well done! You've discovered #FFFF00#a system#REVERT# in a distant constellation . . . but do you know how to reach it? Thanks to the Technology #FFFFFF#Aurigan Shielding#REVERT#, you can reach this system. However, note that fleets can only travel to known destinations. Select one of your fleets and right-click [rightClick] on this new system to travel there.
THE STARS MY DESTINATION

Well done! You've discovered a #FFFF00#system#REVERT# in a distant constellation . . . but do you know how to reach it? In order to travel without lanes, you have to unlock the Technology #FFFFFF#Aurigan Shielding#REVERT# in the Stage 2 of the Science & Exploration quadrant. Note that you can also use the search tool located at the bottom of the Technology Screen.
We are glad to have neighbors, if our neighbors wish to trade peaceably.
We view the passing of friendly ships as a sign of good relations to come.
We remember our years of hardship, and thank you for your generosity.
The Vaulters share your opinion of a certain empire. Common ground may indicate common interests.
A common enemy indicates a common bond. We Aurigans appreciate this.
The Aurigans have needs that must be met, and we feel that you can help us.
We remember much, we Aurigans, and we will remember your open hostility to our people.
You have no cause and no right to take your war to innocent victims!
We seldom welcome strangers. You are not an exception.
We too see the need to travel and explore. But we don't want you doing it in our territory.
We have a long history of fighting for our territory, and against foes more worthy than you. Remove your colony.
Do you really believe that space is a free-for-all? Perhaps we will colonize your territory next.
Boundaries in space are less clear than they were on Auriga.
When friends visit, they usually leave their weapons at home. Why are yours in our space?
We strive to be beacons of virtue, yet you treat us like slaves. You disgust me.
Desperate times require extreme actions; I had no choice but to do what is best for the Aurigans.
We appear to not be enemies. Perhaps the time will come when we can be friends.
You are like mercenaries of the clansmen, who pretend to trade while sharpening their swords.
Many times in our past we have been trapped, cut off, enclosed. Know that it usually goes badly for those who try it.
Your greed is unpleasant, and coming from one we viewed as a friend it is contemptuous.
I will be honest: Aurigans are uneasy exposing ourselves, even to those we trust. We appreciate your willingness to take the same risk.
As First of the Bloodline, I accept your tithe. All Aurigans thank you for your donation.
We can no longer accept your drive to control and conquer. Though they call us Vaulters, we do not run and hide from battle.
My kin are uneasy with your actions and distrust your motives. Our borders are closed, and our hearts cold.
You relent in your desires to take the lives of my people. As First of the Bloodline, I may begin to trust you.
I do not mean to be cruel or arbitrary. I simply do what I must for the Aurigans.
We struck a bargain that benefits everyone. There's nothing wrong with that.
Vaulters seldom forget enemies. But we prefer to see them become friends.
Our tradition of protecting our borders is historic. Thank you for respecting Aurigan territory.
At least you show the honesty of direct attack, rather than pretending your ships were just passing through. Commendable, for vermin.
Apparently you do not take a firm warning from the Aurigans seriously. You insult me and my kin.
I do not care if it is ignorance or aggressiveness. You have decided to ring the bells of war, and the Aurigans do not fear that sound.
Theft of our systems, disrespect of our borders. Your list of provocations grows long, and the famous Vaulter temper grows short.
You treat our territory as if it was your playground. The colony you established is not welcome, and if we come it will not be to play.
Vaulter territory is closed to you. The kin are content to keep you out.
Your constant trespassing reminds us of the incursions of Necrophage scouts. We preferred to slaughter Necrophage scouts.
You will see the Aurigans are an adaptable people. We do not fear cold war or the heat of battle.
Take your Dust and trinkets elsewhere. We would not be bribed by the Clans, and we won't be bribed by you.
This is the behavior we expect from Necrophage insects. Like insects, you will be exterminated.
The Aurigans seek many things. Knowledge is precious, and a pooling of our scientific wisdom would benefit all.
We could better secure our future if we could better secure our revenue. We wonder if a commercial agreement would aid both my kin and your people.
It is time to harvest the true value of peaceful relations--trade! Vaulters are known to be shrewd, but honest.
I speak not only for myself, but for my kin. All Aurigans are content that our peaceful relations have endured when so much else seems ephemeral.
It is good to see the kin thrive; our trade agreement has done much good for the Vaulters.
I would like an explanation for your actions. Is our Peace no longer useful to you?
There is little the Aurigans value more than science, and our agreement has helped us improve our research. Let us hope this cooperation continues.
Would it not be more polite and less abrasive to ask, rather than demand? We do not--or did not--view you as an enemy of the Vaulters.
We note your friendly ships in our space. We Aurigans trust that they plan to remain friendly, and our relationship cordial.
We do not wish to appear demanding. But as First of the Bloodline I have the task to maintain the sovereignty of my kin.
Why are your fleets in our territory? It is like waking up and finding Necrophages have invited themselves to breakfast. You are not ready for a lasting peace.
Perhaps I was not clear. The Aurigans do not want your fleets in our territory. We insist that you remove them.
You were happy to make a demand on my people, yet you feel no need to thank or compensate us. Perhaps you should consider that.
Aurigans tire of waking up and seeing your fleets at our door. You have decided to end this peace; we will move to a status of cold war if practical.
I thank you for removing your fleets from Vaulter territory.
You refuse point blank to make a gesture of thanks or reconciliation? We are no longer interested in agreements and discussions.
I speak for all my kin; we are somewhat reassured by your gesture. Remember that diplomacy is a delicate art, and your hands appear clumsy.
The kin are under pressure; powers of the galaxy that we are ill-prepared to repulse are arrayed against us. What would you say if the Aurigans were to extend a hand?
I see alliances forming that risk doing great damage to my kin. The Aurigan Federacy is beginning to consider alliances.
While we share peaceful relations, others are more willing to do harm to my kin. I wonder if you would consider joining with us. That galaxy is large enough that we can share!
As great alliances form, the Aurigan Federacy feels isolated. Frankly, I am considering proposing an alliance.
We are like doctors, fighting a common plague. My kin begin to wonder if a formal alliance would serve both our interests better.
We have been at peace, you and I, as have our people. My kin are content with this, and voices have begun to whisper thoughts of an alliance.
The shape of power in the galaxy becomes clear. You and I lead our peoples down the same path to success. As allies, this success might become even more secure.
By tradition and by contract, the Aurigans request your aid in our current conflict!
I am sometimes chastized for treating my people too much like family. But such is my weakness, and as an ally, you too are family. And family comes first.
I give you this in thanks for our continued good fortune in this alliance.
Please accept this heartfelt expression of the Aurigans appreciation for our ally.
When friends begin to make demands without a gesture of appreciation, it means the friendship is over. The Aurigans regret what we must do.
I would have thought that the status of "ally" made demands unnecessary. That is how Aurigans treat our friends.
We have seen alliances threatened before, but usually from without. Had you not made this gift, ours would have been threatened from within.
I feel that our alliance holds little value for you; a true friends and ally would understand the difference between "gift" and "pittance."
Ages of seeking and suffereing have made the Vaulters strong and adaptable. We may perhaps adapt to this alliance in its current form, in spite of your past actions.
I speak for my kin when I say better late than never. Would that your aid might have come sooner.
I do not beg. But I do remind you of our alliance and of your promises. You have spurned my kin in our time of need.
You may call it a pleasant name like "conversion", but the Aurigan Federacy cannot tolerate the theft of a system from a so-called ally.
Is it that you lack the courage to wage war, but hide behind propaganda and marketing campaigns? Your continued occupation of Aurigan systems leaves us no choice.
We see this as a gift, as if a member of your kin has joined ours.
We understand the virtues of this unusual presence. Vaulter society hopes to benefit from it.
Your suicidal tendencies are noted. Once we are finished over here, the Aurigan Federacy will be more than happy to bring you down.
This declaration is not out of anger or spite. The Aurigans are throttled in our current situation, and see no choice but to fight our way out.
Your war serves our purpose. My kin see this as an advantageous moment to strike out.
Our populations starve, and you prefer to worsen the situation. Why do you attempt mass murder of my kin?
You butcher civilians like the honorless Necrophage. We destroyed them, and if we must, we will destroy you.
What monster have you conjured among my people? It will not change the course of the war.
I see you are without soul or morals. Apparently butchery is your favorite pastime, and the blood of innocents your favorite drink.
This strange phenomenon you have placed on our system is greatly appreciated, if not entirely understood.
I do not see why you seek to cripple my kin while our empires are at peace. What is the meaning of this sorcery?
I see you are proud of your power and glory, but the Aurigans would prefer to rule themselves. Do not take over our systems--by any means.
At this, the Aurigans draw a line in the snow. You have stolen another system, and we do not believe you have any interest in peace.
The Aurigans are glad you stopped trying to separate them from their kin by converting other systems.
I did not expect this sort of action from you. The Aurigan Federacy appreciates your gesture.
Perhaps you placed this singularity to ensure that this cold war heats up? If you continue, you will learn that as a people we are unafraid of battle.
I would never blockade a system during cold war unless I had very specific intentions. Remove this restriction, or your intentions will be clear.
You have engaged in senseless slaughter of my kin! It is an atrocity that the First of the Bloodline cannot ignore.
Vaulters have a long history of rapidly adapting. Taking the outpost was simple a question of efficiency, not a sign of hostility.
I see that the outpost has gone to you, and not to my kin. The Aurigans are unhappy, but impressed by your effciency.
I do not make demands idly. You chose to ignore it, and the Aurigans see this as an act of disrespect.
I have no desire to go to war at this point; please simply keep your ships out of Vaulter territory.
My kin have suffered long and struggled to survive. The war goes badly for us, and we hope you are not a maniac bent on genocide.
My kin face some concerns that we would rather keep to ourselves. Our borders are closed to you.
Vaulter ships and fleets occasionally need live practice, and your continual provocation has given us an excellent excuse.
My kin are being throttled by frontiers and starlanes; we must expand if we are to survive.
The insanity of this weapon proves the instability of your mind. The Aurigans will see you punished for this.
Why do you gain such pleasure from the mindless slaughter of my people? Do you find such joy in genocide? No sentient could act this way!
You view my kin as targets for your weapons of butchery? If other empires do not destroy you, the gods certainly will.
I thought that the Aurigans would be safe once we accepted your ridiculous demand. But it seems your mind is not stable enough to comprehend this.
It is not that my kin abhor peace, but you use it like a weapon of war.
I expected fleets of ships, not an offer of peace. I will not hide the Aurigans' feeling of releif.
Forcing a peace is like choking someone with dessert. It is not a friendly act, and we still do not trust you.
Your protestations of peaceful appear -- surprisingly -- to be supported by your actions. Vaulter systems are content to see this.
You are skilled at forcing peace, but incapable of understanding it. I and my kin do not understand or trust you.
I see your show of good intent. But a more concrete example of your good will would go far to reassuring the Aurigans.
You are able to both think and listen. In this galaxy that is unusual, and the Aurigans appreciate your efforts.
I have not seen an interest in your part in our well-being. With no show of good faith, I will counsel the Aurigans to treat you with distrust.
Your attempts to suffocate us with peace has only resulted in making the Aurigans angrer.
Save your words. Save your breath. We will no longer speak with you.
You have your fury, and the Vaulters have ours. Time will tell which burns the hotter.
Your action is unacceptable, even in cold war. You stole a system, and I shall have it back.
Your clever propaganda and conversion of systems do not fool us. You have comitted an act of war against the Vaulters, and we will respond in kind.
You spit upon the letter and the spirit of this alliance. The Vaulters will not be spit upon.
The Aurigan Federacy seeks only knowledge, and a true place to call home…
Vaulters are content to win without destroying. We are prepared to offer a truce.
I find your offer interesting; much can be done in peace that cannot be done in war.
I see that the gods do not favor the Aurigans this time. I ask for a truce.
Only the gods really know how this may have ended, but we are content to accept your offer of a truce.
My kin are unhappy with your provocations. Peace does not honestly describe our current relations.
Your insistance at increased tensions between us may come back to haunt you. The Aurigans do not always seek war, but we never fear it.
Your obvious contempt for me and my people is intolerable. Our alliance is nullified, and the Vaulters prepare for the worst.
I am stunned that you so violently withdraw from an alliance to agitate for war. Aurigans have long memories, and this will not be forgotten.
Even among Vaulters bad blood occurs. We had hoped the truce would last, but you do not permit that.
Was this truce your flimsy excuse to re-arm and attack my kin? You will regret the day you chose this deception.
I am not a violent person, but in this case I am forced to do what is best for my kin: war.
As First of the Bloodline I both acknowledge and accept this declaration. You will have a belly full of war before this is over.
The Aurigans tire of your actions and words. The only way to force you to listen, is to use force.
Vaulters have had many enemies before you, and will doubtless have many more after you are gone. It is war!
Life is full of unfortunate necessities. I do not take war or the lives of my kin lightly. But our alliance must be broken, and the dogs of war unchained.
It is difficult for me to see this as anything other than the utmost treachery. Your lack of morals gives the advantage, and the ships of the Aurigan Federacy will do the rest.
So a truce was not to your liking. Not enough Aurigan blood spilled? Not enough innocents murdered? Regardless, we are the Vaulters. We do not tremble before you.
I do not believe that cold war benefits either of our people. I offer the branch of peace, and the hopes of better relations.
I will not be the one to refuse this offer. May the Aurigans and your peoples prosper from more peaceful relations.
Your words are lovely, but your actions the opposite. I do not trust this peace you propose.
Your words are lovely, but your actions the opposite. I do not trust this peace you propose.
Your words are lovely, but your actions the opposite. I do not trust this peace you propose.
Your words are lovely, but your actions the opposite. I do not trust this peace you propose.
The Aurigans have had enough of provocations and pointless skirmishes. Let us end this, and form an alliance to face the dangers of the galaxy together.
I did not expect this! I believe that my kin will accept, and I will not stand in their way. Let us see what this brings us.
The Aurigan Federacy, quite frankly, does not trust you. We are not prepared to be allies.
The Aurigan Federacy, quite frankly, does not trust you. We are not prepared to be allies.
It seems to be a logical step. We can gain more and achieve more in an alliance, shoulder to shoulder.
The Aurigans have learned to trust you. Our peace was fruitful, and we hope the alliance will be doubly so.
We are not ready for this; not yet. I am oathbound to guard the interests of my people, and this alliance would not serve them.
We are not ready for this; not yet. I am oathbound to guard the interests of my people, and this alliance would not serve them.
As First of the Bloodline and leader of the great Aurigan people, I offer you this proposal.
It is not as welcome summer on Auriga, but it is certainly agreeable. I accept your proposal.
I do not feel that this proposal does sufficient honor to my kin. I cannot accept it.
I do not feel that this proposal does sufficient honor to my kin. I cannot accept it.
I do not have time to speak, and my kin are not concerned with your queries.
I will do, and have always done, what is necessary for my kin.
So this is what you desire? I have learned much today.
The Aurigan Federacy salutes those who share our ideals of knowledge and independence.
I am generally suspicious of diplomatic compliments, but your words are greatly appreciated.
My kin and I find you faithless and repulsive; you are like Necrophages, but with fancier guns.
If I was as thin-skinned and insecure as you are, this might bother me.
Do not take this as an insult, but as a simple expression of our needs.
I do not know if I will comply. But the Aurigans will not forget how you treated us.
I do not care if you think that the Aurigans have not been provoked. I feel that we have, so now it is war.
Let me clarify the position of the Vaulters: if you demand this, you better be willing to die for it.
Trade is not the lifeblood of my kin. But we are not so foolish as to let opportunities slip by!
The Aurigans are content to deal with you; may we all grow greater in knowledge and in wealth!
This things you wish to trade are not the things my kin value. You are like the least useful of the Roving Clans, but with faster mounts.
This things you wish to trade are not the things my kin value. You are like the least useful of the Roving Clans, but with faster mounts.
Our scientific prowess and our seekers of knowledge are widely envied. Would you like to share in our discoveries?
Knowledge is a thing of great value to me and my kin; we are content to accept.
You would suck our brains dry and in return give us little of value, I think. We refuse.
You would suck our brains dry and in return give us little of value, I think. We refuse.
The Aurigans have faced greater threats and greater foes than you. We await battle eagerly, sure of our fleets.
You vacillate like the wind. If you are really sure you want war, the Aurigans are really sure we will win it.
The galaxy is full of wonders, but also of traitors. If you wish to close your borders, we are glad to keep you out.
I am hesitant to give those who are not Aurigans the run of our territory. But risk is sometimes necessary, and we trust that the rewards will be good.
My kin and I are not feeling trustful or friendly at the moment. We do not seek to have the fleets of other peoples sniffing around our systems.
My kin and I are not feeling trustful or friendly at the moment. We do not seek to have the fleets of other peoples sniffing around our systems.
The Aurigans have gotten little but grief for our openness. Our borders and our hearts are now closed to foreigners.
I am prepared--cautiously--to open our borders to other empires. Can you be trusted with this honor?
My counsel is my own. The First of the Bloodline will not speak with you.
Vaulters are also not a gregarious people. But we are content to meet you at last, and hope that our relations enrich us.
I am First of the Bloodline, leader of the people from Auriga known as the Vaulters. May the Great Orrery tick on in our favor.
The Aurigans are questers and seekers of knowledge; we would be content to exchange astronomical data.
The more we seek together, the more we will learn. My kin are content to share our vision.
We do not understand why you suddenly reduce our ability to gather information. That is important to the Vaulters.
If you prefer to have less wealth and power, it does not concern me or my kin.
Our science is the envy of many, and you no longer desire this agreement? I find you both surprising and confused.
Together we can see more and know more. The Aurigans do not find a drawback in any of that.
The information you bring is greatly outweighed by the information you absort. This agreement is not in the interest of the Vaulters.
To map the galaxy and track the stars: it seems unthinkable. Together, however, we will do it!
For many ages we have studied the history and science of the galaxy. Our combined knowledge would be an even greater boon to understanding these things.
A truce suits us; we are content to watch and wait.
I do not exult in destruction. What do you say to a truce?
I would do a disservice to my kin to accept a truce as flimsy as this.
I would do a disservice to my kin to accept a truce as flimsy as this.
We have traveled and learned much of the stars, but we prefer to keep these secrets to ourselves. We are not interested in your maps.
We have traveled and learned much of the stars, but we prefer to keep these secrets to ourselves. We are not interested in your maps.
What we can see is for Aurigan eyes only. We are not interested in you seeing what we see.
What we can see is for Aurigan eyes only. We are not interested in you seeing what we see.
The kin are happy to keep our science to ourselves.
We have been trading for centuries, and can do quite well on our own.
Peace is something that is earned and deserved, not declared and imposed.
This action may seem strange. To the kin, it seems necessary.
The Vaulters insist that you remove your fleets that trespass in our territory.
The Vaulters insist that you remove colonies that border our territory.
The Vaulters insist that you stop attacking our fleets and systems.
The Vaulters insist that you cease this "peaceful" theft of our systems.
The Vaulters insist that you stop drawing the life from people in our systems.
The Vaulters insist that you remove your time manipulations from our systems.
The Vaulters insist that you remove your vines from our systems.
The needs of my kin mean that I must impose this policy.
None of us like being told what to do. Next time ask, don't impose!
Co-operation Protocol
This is an agreement to share faction advantages with the Vaulters.

The Lost Expedition - Resurrection

Success! On the fifth day, the rescue party picked up a weak signal coming from a system of caves within the region that the original team disappeared. Upon investigation, they discovered the team surviving inside a Vodyani craft near the mouth of the caves. Although the crew gave conflicting accounts of what had happened, and possessed equipment that was prematurely aged, they were found to be in fine physical and mental health. After some simple repairs to the Vodyani craft, both the rescue party and the missing crew were able to leave the surface and return to the fleet. Insights gleaned from the whole affair have triggered a scientific renaissance across the empire.
Rescued!

The rescue mission is a success, bringing home not only the missing team, but also a Vodyani vessel. Questions remain as to exactly what happened, but the upshot is that interest in science has never been greater!
Increases [scientistColored] (Scientist) political ideology Spawns Vodyani ship on $QuestSystem01Name System.
The Lost Expedition - Disaster

Grim tidings. It seems your scientific counsel wasn't wrong to warn you that the entire fleet might be in danger should you undertake a rescue mission. Now they're gone, their only visible remains a thin trail of smoke from a mountainous region on the planet. How? Questions remain, but something malicious got into the fleet's navigation computers when the rescue party sent a tight-beam update on the third day. They'd been relaying information about tracking a faint signal from the area in which the original team disappeared, when everything went dark across the entire fleet. Then the fleet's engines fired up full-blast, setting course for the planet. They must've tried to wrest control back, but they weren't successful. Every ship hurtled into the mountainside at hundreds of klicks per second. Nobody would've survived. Unsurprisingly, superstitious thinking across the empire is on the up.
Calamity
Events of the ground involving the rescue team, somehow precipitated the loss of the entire fleet. The news has increased religious fervor across the empire.
Increases [religiousColored] (Religious) political ideology A fleet is destroyed.

Support
Support the Pirates so their next fleet is stronger. This improves your standing with them, and also slightly increases Pirate Power gains.
Covert Sabotage
Anonymously sabotage the Pirate supplies so their next fleet is weaker. This slightly reduces Pirate Power gains.
Buy a Pirate Mark
Buy a Pirate Mark that you can use to put a contract on another empire's system
Non-aggression Pact
Make peace with the Pirates. They won't attack you, you can't be targeted using a Pirate Mark, and you can use their systems as Portals if you have this ability.
Cancel Non-aggression Pact
Cancel the peace. You will be able to attack Pirate fleets and they will be able to attack you. Your Standing with the Pirate League will be reset.
Standing: {0}
Displays your current relation with the Pirate League. When an Empire improves its own relations with the Pirates, it also reduces other Empires' relations with the Pirates.
Disastrous
You are a priority target of the Pirates. If a Mark is placed on you, Pirate fleets will respond to the call from further away in the galaxy
Poor
The Pirates don't like you, and are happy to bother you if a Mark is placed on you.
Wary
You have a neutral standing with the Pirates; only nearby fleets will attack if a Mark is placed on you.
Cordial
You are at peace with the Pirates. Their fleets won't attack you, and other empires cannot place a Pirate Mark on you.
Cordial (forced)

Scientists\nMilitarists

An ancient faction, the Vaulters suffered continual setbacks in 
trying to establish a permanent home for themselves. Not so 
much restless wanderers as adaptable pragmatists, their 
centuries of travel and tinkering have made them skilled at 
both science and warfare. Defense remains their preferred 
military strategy, and their grim tenacity makes them effective 
defenders. They have a tradition of appointing female leaders, 
and their history of escaping and surviving to fight another day 
continually reaffirms it.

The Vaulters, led by the wily and resilient Zolya clan, have taken their place as leaders of the galaxy!

You can call it victory, but your history shows that positions of power are often fleeting. Regardless, you should savor the moment; powerful, independent, and widely respected, the Vaulter kin are the undisputed masters of the galaxy.
